1. Morse API¶

>>> import morse.code
>>> p = morse.code.TelegraphPrinter()
>>> p.encode("SMS SMS")
'...--...   ...--...'
>>> w = morse.code.TelegraphWriter("test.ogg")
>>> w.encode("SMS SMS")
Exports the Morse for "SMS SMS" to test.ogg
>>> p = morse.code.TelegraphPlayer()
>>> p.encode("SMS SMS")
Plays the Morse for "SMS SMS" to test.ogg

2. Telegraph¶

class morse.code.Telegraph(morse_alphabet='international')¶

Warning

This class is used primarily as a parent class to be inherited from. Please see TelegraphWriter ,:class:TelegraphPlayer OR TelegraphPrinter. It is created as a “new style” class.

Parameters:morse_alphabet – (str) Name of alphabet encoding to be used.
generate_code(character, ignore_unknown=True)¶

Return the Morse encoding of a character, according to the configured alphabet

Parameters:

character – (str) Character to be encoded
Returns:

‘.-‘ encoding of character
Return type:

String
Raises:
  • TypeError – If a single character is not passed
  • CharacterNotFound – if ignore_unknown is set to False and a character is not found
generate_tones(frequency=660, wpm=20, rate=44100)¶

Generate character tones

The ‘.’ and ‘-‘ Morse characters are represented by a NumPy array data structure. The structure, and the tone are affected by the frequency of the ‘note’ (the default, 660Hz is the musical note ‘A’), the Words Per Minute (the number of words per minute defines how long each tone will be) and the sample rate (the frequency at which the tone is passed to the sound card).

When an instance of a subclass of the class:Telegraph is created the tones can be regenerated. For example, to change the note to a middle C (frequency 262Hz), with a slower WPM rate

>>> p = morse.code.TelegraphPlayer()
>>> p.generate_tones(frequency=262, wpm=10)
Parameters:
  • frequency – (int) Tone frequency. Default 660Hz is ‘A’
  • wpm – (int) Words per minute. Determines the length of a ‘.’ and ‘-‘.
  • rate – (int) Sample rate.
get_tone(character, ignore_unknown=True)¶

Return the Morse Code NumPy Array for a character

Parameters:
  • character – (str) alphabetic character, in the range A-Z, a-z and 0-9
  • ignore_unknown – (bool) Return a blank character if the character is not found, or raise an CharacterNotFound exception
Raises:
  • TypeError – If a single character is not passed
  • CharacterNotFound – if ignore_unknown is set to False and a character is not found
silence()¶

Return the data structure for a tones length of silence.

This can be used to populate the gaps between characters (2 ‘.’ tones) or the gap between words (5 ‘.’ tones)

Returns:a single ‘.’ tones worth of silence.
Return type:NumPy array

2.1. TelegraphWriter¶

class morse.code.TelegraphWriter(filename, audio_format='ogg', audio_encoding='vorbis', alphabet='international')¶

Bases: morse.code.Telegraph

Write Morse Code to an Audio File. TelegraphWriter uses SndFile from the scikits.audiolab package to write out audio data, and as such TelegraphWriter can output to whatever formats are available. See the available_file_formats() and available_encodings() to determine what audio outputs are available.

Parameters:
  • filename – (str) Filename to output to
  • audio_format – (str) Audio format
  • audio_encoding – (str) Encoding of audio_format
  • alphabet – (str) Morse Code alphabet to be used
Raises InvalidFormatEncoding:
 

The default format and encoding is ogg vorbis (http://www.vorbis.com). This produces good quality compressed files, but is slower that (say) WAV 16pcm

encode(message)¶

Write a message to the output file.

Parameters:message – (str) Message to be written
Raises CharacterNotFound:
 if ignore_unknown is set to False and a character is not found

2.2. TelegraphPlayer¶

class morse.code.TelegraphPlayer(morse_alphabet='international')¶

Bases: morse.code.Telegraph

Play the Morse Code through the audio device

Parameters:alphabet – (str) Morse Code alphabet to be used
encode(message)¶

Play a message to the output device.

Parameters:message – (str) Message to be played
Raises CharacterNotFound:
 if ignore_unknown is set to False and a character is not found

3. Exceptions¶

class morse.code.CharacterNotFound(char)¶

Exception returned if an encoding is not available for a character

class morse.code.InvalidFormatEncoding(audio_format=None, audio_encoding=None)¶

Exception returned if an encoding is not available for an audio format
